study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between dietary magnesium intake and chronic inflammatory stress, as well as its potential role in reducing the risk of chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that moderate magnesium deficiency is linked to increased inflammatory markers like CRP, and magnesium supplementation can reduce CRP levels, suggesting a protective effect against chronic diseases such as hypertension, heart disease, and diabetes.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate or marginal magnesium deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single-loading dose of intravenous magnesium could improve insulin resistance indices in critically ill patients with stress-induced hyperglycemia.
results_summary: The study found that a single-loading dose of intravenous magnesium significantly increased serum and intracellular magnesium levels and improved insulin resistance indices in critically ill patients with stress-induced hyperglycemia.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients without diabetes but with stress-induced hyperglycemia.
effective_dosage: 7.5 g of magnesium sulfate in 500 mL normal saline as intravenous infusion over an 8-hour period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of oral magnesium supplementation on blood pressure and hemodynamic parameters in patients with essential hypertension.
results_summary: After one month of magnesium supplementation, systolic and diastolic blood pressures significantly decreased, along with improvements in various hemodynamic parameters measured via impedance cardiography.
population_specificity: 48 patients (19 men, 29 women) with essential hypertension on stable antihypertensive therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium, in combination with zinc and chromium, could improve metabolic risk factors in adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in metabolic risk factors post-intervention, but a decrease in serum C-reactive protein levels was observed in the mineral-supplemented group compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome (n=32, 16 in each group).
effective_dosage: 300 mg magnesium per day, combined with 600 μg chromium and 36 mg zinc.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation reduces cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in pediatric cancer patients.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced the incidence of grade 2 or higher creatinine elevation (9.8% vs. 22.7%, P=0.025) and was associated with less cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity. Multivariate analysis confirmed magnesium's protective effect (odds ratio 0.36).
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with newly diagnosed cancer receiving cisplatin-containing chemotherapy.
study_duration: Duration of chemotherapy courses (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of magnesium supplementation on endothelial function, specifically flow-mediated dilation (FMD) and carotid intima media thickness (CIMT).
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved FMD but had no significant effect on CIMT, with high heterogeneity observed across studies. Subgroup analysis suggested greater CIMT reduction in hemodialysis patients and with specific dosing and baseline conditions.
population_specificity: 306 participants across seven RCTs, including hemodialysis patients and individuals with varying health statuses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review randomized controlled trials assessing the effect of nutritional supplements, including magnesium, on migraine patients.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplementation, among other nutrients, may play a role in migraine prevention, though further research is needed for conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Migraine patients (6% of men and 18% of women worldwide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the magnesium release profile and bioavailability of a low-dose continuous-release magnesium chloride tablet (ChronoMag®) with a reference tablet at a standard dose (300 mg).
results_summary: The low-dose formulation provided continuous magnesium release for 6 hours, compared to the reference tablet's complete release within 1 hour. Cumulative urinary magnesium levels were 76-89% of the reference tablet's levels, suggesting improved absorption and bioavailability.
population_specificity: 12 normo-magnesemic healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 100 mg magnesium element (two 50 mg tablets once daily) for ChronoMag®; 300 mg magnesium element (three 100 mg tablets) for the reference tablet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of magnesium supplementation in reducing vascular damage and mortality, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: Low magnesium levels were associated with increased cardiovascular and all-cause mortality in hemodialysis patients. Magnesium supplementation reduced vascular calcifications and mortality in animal models of uremia and decreased osteogenic transdifferentiation of vascular smooth muscle cells in vitro.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease, particularly hemodialysis patients, and the general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation could prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients with head and neck cancer.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium-supplemented hydration significantly reduced the decline in creatinine clearance compared to the crystalloid-only regimen, with multivariate analysis confirming magnesium supplementation as an independent predictive factor for preventing nephrotoxicity.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer receiving cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 20 mEq of magnesium sulfate in 1000 mL of 0.9% saline administered for 3 hours before cisplatin infusion.
study_duration: Two courses of chemotherapy, 3 weeks apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the absorption, cellular uptake, and clinical effectiveness of a timed-release magnesium formulation (MagSRT™) in improving magnesium status in a standard clinical population.
results_summary: MagSRT™ significantly improved magnesium status, increasing RBC magnesium by 6% at 30 days and 30% at 90 days, while symptom scores improved by 28% and 63%, respectively, with minimal gastrointestinal side effects.
population_specificity: 91 adults from a standard clinical population, with 53 receiving MagSRT™ and 38 receiving a placebo.
effective_dosage: 500 mg dimagnesium malate (2 tablets of 250 mg magnesium each) daily.
study_duration: 30 days for the main trial, with a subset continuing for 90 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on the transcription of TRPM6, TRPM7, and SLC41A1 in individuals with incident pre-hypertension.
results_summary: Oral magnesium supplementation significantly increased leukocyte TRPM6 mRNA relative expression but had no significant effect on TRPM7 or SLC41A1 mRNA expression in pre-hypertensive individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with incident pre-hypertension, excluding those with hypertension, diabetes, alcohol intake, chronic diarrhea, diuretic use, magnesium supplementation, or reduced renal function.
effective_dosage: 360 mg elemental magnesium (as magnesium lactate) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature to understand magnesium's role in the pathogenesis of breast cancer, focusing on its metabolism, bioavailability, and impact on tumor progression.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium plays a role in breast cancer progression by increasing intracellular concentrations via upregulated transport channels, which may contribute to tumor growth. However, the data were inconsistent and limited, highlighting the need for further research.
population_specificity: Studies reviewed involved breast cancer patients and magnesium metabolism, but no specific demographic details were provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium supplementation on gene expression related to insulin and lipid metabolism in women with gestational diabetes (GDM) not on oral hypoglycemic agents.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly decreased fasting plasma glucose levels and upregulated gene expression of PPAR-γ and GLUT-1 while downregulating LDLR expression in PBMCs of women with GDM. A trend toward decreased LP(a) gene expression was also observed.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-40 years diagnosed with gestational diabetes (GDM) not on oral hypoglycemic agents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of magnesium supplementation in alleviating chemotherapy-induced fatigue in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between PC-18 (containing magnesium silicate) and placebo in reducing fatigue, possibly due to unexpected placebo effects. Higher baseline magnesium levels and fatigue scores correlated with poorer outcomes, suggesting a complex relationship between magnesium and fatigue.
population_specificity: Early breast cancer patients experiencing increased fatigue after their first cycle of adjuvant chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Approximately 100 mg of magnesium silicate per capsule (as an excipient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium and zinc co-supplementation on biomarkers of inflammation, oxidative stress, and gene expression related to inflammation in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Magnesium and zinc co-supplementation significantly reduced serum hs-CRP and PCO levels, increased plasma TAC, and downregulated gene expression of IL-1 and TNF-α in PBMCs of PCOS subjects compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-40 with PCOS diagnosed by Rotterdam criteria.
effective_dosage: 250 mg magnesium oxide plus 220 mg zinc sulfate (containing 50 mg zinc) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low serum magnesium levels are associated with increased mortality and cardiovascular disease in individuals with and without chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: Low serum magnesium levels were independently associated with a higher risk of all-cause death in both CKD and non-CKD subgroups, with a 20-40% increased hazard per 0.2 mg/dL decrease. In CKD patients, the lowest magnesium tertile showed a significantly higher adjusted hazard ratio for all-cause death compared to the highest tertile.
population_specificity: Multiethnic cohort from the Dallas Heart Study, including participants with and without chronic kidney disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study analyzed serum magnesium levels, not supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of magnesium-zinc-calcium-vitamin D co-supplementation on glycemic control and cardio-metabolic risk markers in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The co-supplementation significantly improved insulin metabolism (reduced serum insulin and insulin resistance, increased insulin sensitivity) and reduced cardio-metabolic risk markers (lower triglycerides, VLDL-cholesterol, total cholesterol, and total-/HDL-cholesterol ratio).
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
effective_dosage: 100 mg magnesium, 4 mg zinc, 400 mg calcium, and 200 IU vitamin D twice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits and risks of magnesium supplementation in dialysis patients, focusing on its effects on serum phosphate, PTH, vascular calcification, and mortality.
results_summary: The study suggests that magnesium supplementation may help reduce serum phosphate, PTH, and vascular calcification, and could lower all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, though results are conflicting. Additional research is needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients
interactions: Medications (antacids, phosphate binders) and diet mentioned as factors affecting serum magnesium levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between chronic magnesium deficiency and major disorders, and whether oral magnesium supplementation should be considered in high-risk patients despite normal serum magnesium levels.
results_summary: The study found that chronic magnesium deficiency is linked to and worsens several major disorders, yet serum magnesium levels often remain within normal ranges, masking deficiency. The authors suggest pragmatic tests for assessing magnesium status and highlight the importance of magnesium for cellular function and bone health.
population_specificity: High-risk patients with potential chronic magnesium deficiency (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify normal and tolerable ranges of serum magnesium (sMg) concentrations in neonates and identify factors influencing these levels.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium levels in newborns without supplementation were similar to maternal levels at birth but increased during the first week of life. Elevated magnesium levels (>2.5 mmol/L) were associated with adverse effects, but levels up to 2.0 mmol/L were well tolerated.
population_specificity: Neonates (newborns), with a focus on those with and without prenatal magnesium supplementation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study analyzed existing data rather than administering doses).
study_duration: Not specified (study reviewed data from birth through the first week of life).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation improves insulin secretion and glycemic control in hypomagnesemic kidney transplant recipients on tacrolimus.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation (mean daily dose 688±237 mg) did not significantly improve insulin secretion, fasting glucose, HbA1c, or insulin resistance. Persisting hypomagnesemia was associated with worse glucose tolerance and lower dietary magnesium intake.
population_specificity: Hypomagnesemic kidney transplant recipients on tacrolimus, more than 4 months post-transplant.
effective_dosage: Up to 3 times 450 mg magnesium oxide daily (mean 688±237 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence on magnesium status/supplementation in relation to exercise performance, summarizing findings from both animal and human studies.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium may improve exercise performance by enhancing glucose availability and reducing lactate accumulation. Human studies showed positive associations between magnesium status and muscle performance, with supplementation improving functional indices like quadriceps torque, gait speed, and chair stand time in elderly women.
population_specificity: Physically active individuals and elderly women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of magnesium homeostasis and supplementation in mitigating cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in children.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of magnesium in addressing cisplatin-related nephrotoxicity but does not provide specific efficacy data on magnesium supplementation. It emphasizes the need for better understanding and management of these toxicities.
population_specificity: Children treated with cisplatin for cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of Mg supplementation on muscular damage markers and the association between serum Mg levels and these markers in young athletes.
results_summary: Serum Mg levels initially decreased but later increased significantly by the end of the study. Muscle damage parameters remained stable, except for creatinine, which fluctuated. The results suggest Mg supplementation may prevent tissue damage during competition.
population_specificity: Twelve elite male basketball players and twelve university students who played recreational basketball.
study_duration: Approximately six months (from October to April).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium supplementation can prevent the progression of coronary artery calcification in subjects with predialysis chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes the design and rationale of an ongoing clinical trial (pre-results).
population_specificity: Subjects with predialysis chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate of 15 to 45 mL/min/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on plasma C-reactive protein (CRP) concentrations through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation did not significantly affect CRP levels overall but showed a significant reduction in individuals with baseline CRP levels > 3 mg/L. No effect was observed in those with CRP ≤ 3 mg/L.
population_specificity: Individuals with varying baseline CRP levels (both ≤ 3 mg/L and > 3 mg/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether over-the-counter magnesium chloride supplementation improves symptoms of depression in adults with mild-to-moderate depression.
results_summary: Magnesium chloride supplementation for 6 weeks resulted in clinically significant improvements in depression (PHQ-9 scores) and anxiety (GAD-7 scores), with high adherence and good tolerability. Participants reported willingness to continue using magnesium in the future, and effects were consistent across subgroups.
population_specificity: 126 adults (mean age 52; 38% male) diagnosed with mild-to-moderate depression (PHQ-9 scores 5-19).
effective_dosage: 248 mg of elemental magnesium per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium supplementation on wound healing and metabolic status in subjects with diabetic foot ulcers (DFU).
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved serum magnesium levels, reduced ulcer dimensions (length, width, depth), enhanced glucose metabolism (lowered fasting glucose, insulin, HbA1c), decreased inflammation (hs-CRP), and increased antioxidant capacity (TAC) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 70 subjects with grade 3 diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between magnesium and vitamin D, focusing on their deficiency states, disease associations, and the importance of magnesium supplementation in vitamin D therapy.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium is essential for vitamin D metabolism and that large doses of vitamin D can deplete magnesium levels. Adequate magnesium supplementation was highlighted as a critical aspect of vitamin D therapy, though screening for magnesium deficiency remains challenging.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mentioned in the context of reducing nonvertebral fractures, overall mortality, and Alzheimer dementia incidence).
interactions: Large doses of vitamin D can induce severe magnesium depletion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of magnesium supplementation in preventing cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplementation may have a nephroprotective role in patients receiving cisplatin, though the evidence was limited to a subset of the reviewed studies.
population_specificity: Cancer patients treated with cisplatin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of magnesium supplementation in alleviating subjective anxiety and stress symptoms in vulnerable populations.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with magnesium showing positive effects on anxiety in some vulnerable samples (mildly anxious, PMS, hypertensive) but no effect on postpartum anxiety. The overall quality of evidence was deemed poor.
population_specificity: Mildly anxious individuals, premenstrual syndrome (PMS) patients, postpartum individuals, and hypertensive patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding MgSO4 to dilute ropivacaine provides equivalent analgesia to higher concentrations of ropivacaine alone for diabetic patients undergoing toe amputations with sciatic nerve blocks.
results_summary: Adding 200 mg MgSO4 to 0.25% ropivacaine prolonged sensory block duration and reduced postoperative analgesic consumption compared to 0.25% ropivacaine alone, but it did not significantly improve analgesic quality over 0.375% ropivacaine.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients undergoing toe amputations.
effective_dosage: 200 mg MgSO4 added to 0.25% ropivacaine (single perineural administration).
study_duration: Outcomes were assessed up to 48 hours postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium supplementation reduces gastrointestinal complications in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation reduced postoperative hypomagnesemia, atrial fibrillation, nausea, vomiting, and constipation, though hypomagnesemia persisted in many intervention group patients, suggesting higher doses may be needed.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery (102 participants, 52 in intervention, 50 in control).
effective_dosage: 800 mg magnesium oxide (240 mg elemental magnesium per tablet, 2 tablets daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transdermal magnesium absorption via a cream could improve magnesium status in humans compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found a clinically relevant increase in serum magnesium levels (8.54%) and urinary magnesium excretion (9.1%) in the magnesium cream group, though statistical significance was only achieved for serum magnesium in non-athletes. The placebo group showed minimal changes.
population_specificity: 25 participants (aged 34.3±14.8 years, height 171.5±11 cm, weight 75.9±14 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and systematize evidence on the efficacy and pharmacological mechanisms of oral magnesium supplementation for gynecological conditions such as premenstrual syndrome, dysmenorrhea, and climacteric symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplementation is effective in preventing dysmenorrhea, premenstrual syndrome, menstrual migraine, and climacteric symptoms, with positive correlations between magnesium administration and symptom relief.
population_specificity: Women with gynecological conditions (premenstrual syndrome, dysmenorrhea, postmenopausal symptoms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of magnesium supplementation on insulin resistance (IR) in humans through a systematic review of clinical trials.
results_summary: The review found that magnesium supplementation influenced fasting glucose concentrations in eight trials, fasting insulin levels in five trials, and reduced IR values in seven studies. The data suggest benefits for reducing IR in hypomagnesemic patients with IR, but further studies are needed to standardize supplementation protocols.
population_specificity: Patients with hypomagnesemia presenting insulin resistance, with no restrictions on sex, age, or ethnicity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (differential dosing/shape of magnesium was considered without restriction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between serum magnesium levels and glycemic control/lipid profile in children with type 1 diabetes and assess the effects of oral magnesium supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplementation significantly reduced HbA1c, triglycerides, LDL, and total cholesterol while increasing HDL in hypomagnesemic diabetic children. Serum magnesium levels were negatively correlated with HbA1c and atherogenic lipids and positively correlated with protective lipids.
population_specificity: 71 children (32 males, 39 females) with type 1 diabetes, mean age 9.68 ± 3.99 years, from a pediatric endocrinology clinic in Egypt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term magnesium supplementation improves endothelial function and cardiometabolic risk markers in overweight and obese adults.
results_summary: The study found that a daily magnesium supplement of 350 mg for 24 weeks did not improve endothelial function or cardiometabolic risk markers, including brachial artery flow-mediated vasodilation, reactive hyperemia index, retinal microvascular caliber, and plasma markers for microvascular endothelial function. No significant effects were observed on serum lipids, plasma glucose, insulin sensitivity, or low-grade systemic inflammation.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese middle-aged and elderly adults (30 men and 22 women, age 62 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of magnesium supplementation on depression status in magnesium-deficient depressed patients.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation (500 mg/day) significantly improved serum magnesium levels and reduced depression scores more than placebo, with 88.5% of the treatment group achieving normal magnesium levels versus 48.1% in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 60 depressed patients with hypomagnesemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of magnesium supplementation on metabolic profiles in hypomagnesemic, pre-diabetic, obese patients with mild-to-moderate chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved insulin resistance, HOMA-IR index, hemoglobin A1c, insulin levels, waist circumference, uric acid, albumin, and serum magnesium levels compared to placebo. However, changes in metabolic syndrome, obesity, pre-diabetes, and blood pressure were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Hypomagnesemic, pre-diabetic, obese patients with mild-to-moderate chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate between 90 and 30 ml/min/1.73m²).
effective_dosage: 365 mg of oral magnesium once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium oxide is more effective than placebo in preventing nocturnal leg cramps (NLC) in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between magnesium oxide and placebo in reducing the frequency, severity, or duration of NLC, nor in improving quality of life or sleep. The observed reduction in NLC in both groups was likely due to a placebo effect.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling individuals aged 21 or older experiencing frequent nocturnal leg cramps (4+ episodes during a 2-week screening).
effective_dosage: Once daily at bedtime (specific amount not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of magnesium in cardiovascular health, particularly its potential to mitigate cardiovascular risks and vascular calcification in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that lower serum magnesium levels were associated with higher cardiovascular mortality in CKD patients, while higher magnesium levels alleviated risks linked to hyperphosphatemia and vascular calcification. Magnesium supplementation improved blood pressure control, insulin sensitivity, and endothelial function.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), including those receiving dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on lipid profiles in both diabetic and non-diabetic individuals through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of magnesium supplementation on plasma concentrations of total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, or triglycerides in either diabetic or non-diabetic individuals. Subgroup analysis also showed no differences between diabetic and non-diabetic participants in terms of lipid profile changes.
population_specificity: Diabetic and non-diabetic individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of magnesium supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) in both diabetic and nondiabetic individuals.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved fasting plasma glucose (FPG), HDL, LDL, triglycerides (TG), and systolic blood pressure (SBP), suggesting it may reduce cardiovascular disease risk in T2D patients.
population_specificity: Diabetic and nondiabetic individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of magnesium supplementation on mortality and vascular calcification in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that while magnesium supplementation might have favorable effects on vascular calcification, existing RCTs failed to demonstrate any significant benefit on mortality in CKD patients. The association between low serum magnesium levels and increased cardiovascular mortality was noted, but direct evidence supporting supplementation was limited.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients (stages 1 to 5 and 5D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of acute exercise on ionized and total plasma magnesium levels in endurance athletes.
results_summary: The study measured fluctuations in magnesium levels (iMg and tMg) in response to exercise but did not report specific outcomes regarding performance or health benefits.
population_specificity: 18 healthy, well-trained endurance athletes (age 31.1 ± 8.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of magnesium in biochemical processes, its association with depression, and the potential benefits of magnesium supplementation in enhancing conventional antidepressant treatments.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium deficiency is linked to depressive behavior, which can be reversed by antidepressant drugs. Magnesium supplementation was shown to be well-tolerated and effective in improving mood, enhancing the efficacy of standard antidepressant treatments, though bioavailability differences between inorganic and organic compounds should be considered.
population_specificity: Rodents and general human populations with conditions leading to magnesium deficiency (e.g., poor nutrition, gastrointestinal/renal diseases, diabetes, alcoholism, stress).

study_goal: To examine the analgesic effect and safety of single-dose intra-articular magnesium after arthroscopic surgery.
results_summary: Intra-articular magnesium significantly reduced pain scores compared to placebo and enhanced the analgesic effect of bupivacaine without increasing adverse reactions. Experimental studies also suggested a chondrocyte protective effect of magnesium.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing arthroscopic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of magnesium (Mg) supplementation as a novel treatment for subjective anxiety, particularly in mildly anxious individuals and those with premenstrual syndrome-related anxiety.
results_summary: The study suggests a beneficial effect of Mg intake on subjective anxiety in mildly anxious individuals and those with premenstrual syndrome-related anxiety, though further randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Mildly anxious individuals and those reporting premenstrual syndrome-related anxiety.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the adequacy of current Dietary Recommended Intakes (DRIs) for magnesium and assess the reliability of urinary and serum magnesium as indicators of magnesium status.
results_summary: The study found that current DRIs for magnesium may be overestimated, urinary magnesium is useful for population studies but not individual assessment, and serum magnesium concentrations above 0.75 mmol/L may still indicate a deficit responsive to supplementation.
population_specificity: 70-kg healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate magnesium's potential in preventing and treating cardiac arrhythmias, including its role in improving antiarrhythmic drug efficacy and safety.
results_summary: Magnesium regulates ion channels in myocardial tissues and shows therapeutic potential for arrhythmias, but gaps exist in linking intracellular magnesium correction to clinical outcomes, with limitations like small sample sizes and varying administration methods.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., torsade de pointes, atrial fibrillation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium supplementation on blood pressure and vascular function in thiazide-treated hypertensive women.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, improved endothelial function (measured by FMD), and prevented the progression of carotid intima-media thickness compared to placebo. No effects were observed on plasma glucose, lipids, or arterial stiffness parameters.
population_specificity: Hypertensive women (40-65 years) on hydrochlorothiazide with mean 24-h BP ≥130/80 mmHg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between postoperative electrolyte levels (potassium and magnesium) and the occurrence of atrial fibrillation after cardiac surgery.
results_summary: Higher magnesium levels were associated with increased risk of postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF), and magnesium supplementation was linked to higher POAF rates (47% vs. 36%). Magnesium was an independent predictor of POAF.
population_specificity: 2,041 adult patients without preoperative atrial fibrillation who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting, valve operation, or both.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review updated information on magnesium's role in oxidative stress in obesity.
results_summary: The study found that obese individuals have low serum magnesium levels and high oxidative stress markers, and adequate magnesium intake helps maintain homeostasis and mitigate oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Obese individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and implications of magnesium deficiency in pregnant women and evaluate the reliability of current testing methods.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium deficiency is common in pregnant women and may increase risks for conditions like gestational diabetes, preterm labor, and preeclampsia. It also highlighted limitations in serum magnesium testing and recommended improved methods like red cell magnesium measurement.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age, particularly pregnant women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on glucose and insulin-sensitivity parameters in individuals with diabetes or at high risk of diabetes compared to placebo.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation reduced fasting plasma glucose and improved insulin sensitivity compared to placebo, with a moderate effect size (SMD=-0.40). The study included 18 RCTs, supporting consistent but modest benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes or at high risk of diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pharmacokinetic profile of magnesium hydroxide after a single oral dose in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study provided a pharmacokinetic profile of magnesium hydroxide but did not report specific efficacy outcomes or clinical effects. The abstract does not detail the results beyond the study design.
population_specificity: Ten healthy male adults
study_duration: Single dose, with three 24-hour study days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on blood pressure in adults by synthesizing evidence from randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trials.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure by 2.00 mm Hg and 1.78 mm Hg, respectively, and elevated serum magnesium levels. Greater reductions in blood pressure were observed in high-quality trials or those with low dropout rates.
population_specificity: Normotensive and hypertensive adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium supplementation on endothelial progenitor cell (EPC) function and oxidative stress in healthy men and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly increased EPC colony formation and reduced oxidative stress markers (free radical levels and TBARS scores) in both healthy men and SHRs. It also suppressed nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate oxidase component mRNA expression in SHRs, indicating antioxidative benefits.
population_specificity: Healthy men and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
effective_dosage: 340 mg per day for humans; 600 mg per 100 g diet for SHRs.
study_duration: 2 weeks for humans; 4 weeks for SHRs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplements containing magnesium, probiotics, and vitamins could reduce psychological stress and fatigue in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation significantly reduced psychological stress (22.7% reduction) and fatigue (45% reduction), with benefits maintained one month after discontinuation.
population_specificity: 242 healthy volunteers (79.8% women, average age 38.6±13.6 years) with high perceived stress (PSS 10 score >21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether four-week magnesium supplementation could prevent or reduce DNA damage in sedentary students and rugby players.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced high DNA damage in both groups and medium DNA damage in rugby players compared to controls, suggesting protective effects against oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Sedentary students and rugby players.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of long-term magnesium supplementation on arterial stiffness in overweight and slightly obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that 24-week magnesium supplementation (350 mg/d) improved arterial stiffness (measured by PWVc-f) but did not affect blood pressure. Serum magnesium levels and urinary excretion increased, indicating effective absorption.
population_specificity: Overweight and slightly obese individuals (30 men and 22 postmenopausal women, mean age 62 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on insulin sensitivity and glucose control in diabetic and non-diabetic individuals.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved the HOMA-IR index, particularly with durations ≥4 months, but did not significantly affect plasma glucose, HbA1c, or insulin levels overall. Longer supplementation (≥4 months) showed greater benefits for fasting glucose and HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: Diabetic and non-diabetic individuals.
study_duration: Subgroup analysis compared <4 months versus ≥4 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and effectiveness of high-dose (10 gm) versus low-dose (5 gm) magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) in reducing atrial fibrillation (AF) incidence after coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery.
results_summary: The study found that MgSO4 was safe and effective in reducing AF incidence post-CABG, with no significant difference between high and low doses. AF occurred in 10.23% of patients, with no statistical difference between dosage groups, and only one minor adverse event (flushing and abdominal discomfort) was reported in the high-dose group.
population_specificity: Elective CABG surgery patients (n=88).
effective_dosage: High dose (10 gm) and low dose (5 gm) MgSO4.
study_duration: Administered perioperatively, with monitoring for 24 hours post-surgery and clinical observation until discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the management strategies for EGFRI-induced hypomagnesemia, including the effectiveness and safety of intravenous and oral magnesium replacement.
results_summary: High-dose intravenous magnesium replacement did not sustain magnesium repletion beyond 72 hours in most patients with severe hypomagnesemia, and oral supplementation was ineffective and poorly tolerated. Severe hypomagnesemia was associated with adverse effects like tachycardia and mental alterations, and resolution typically occurred weeks to months after discontinuing EGFRI therapy.
population_specificity: Adult patients treated with EGFRIs who developed hypomagnesemia.
effective_dosage: High-dose intravenous magnesium (specific amount not stated).
interactions: Concomitant platinum chemotherapy was noted as a risk factor for severe hypomagnesemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a dietary supplement containing magnesium and other micronutrients could improve cardiometabolic parameters in chronically stressed individuals.
results_summary: The study found a reduction in fasting serum insulin concentrations in the treatment group after dietary intervention, suggesting potential metabolic benefits. An association was observed between psychological stress scores, baseline insulin levels, and insulin reduction after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: 32 patients with chronic stress disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Chinese herbal medicines, including combinations with pharmaceuticals like magnesium sulphate, for treating unexplained recurrent miscarriage.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence suggesting that combining Chinese herbal medicines with pharmaceuticals (including magnesium sulphate) may improve continuing pregnancy and live birth rates compared to pharmaceuticals alone, but methodological quality was poor.
population_specificity: Women with unexplained recurrent miscarriage (861 women across nine trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of oral magnesium supplementation in controlling severe pain in patients with advanced peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD).
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not provide results, as it is a planned clinical trial.
population_specificity: Adult patients with PAOD at stages III and IV of Lèriche-Fontaine classification, who are opioid-naïve and experiencing intractable pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on magnesium homeostasis in cystic fibrosis patients and assess its potential impact on disease progression and treatment.
results_summary: The review found that hypomagnesemia is common in advanced cystic fibrosis, decreases with age, and may be worsened by aminoglycoside use. Magnesium supplementation might improve respiratory muscle strength and mucolytic activity.
population_specificity: Cystic fibrosis patients, particularly those with advanced disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a short hydration protocol with magnesium supplementation compared to conventional hydration in patients receiving cisplatin chemotherapy.
results_summary: The short hydration protocol with magnesium supplementation resulted in significantly lower rates of elevated serum creatinine levels (≥grade 1) compared to conventional hydration, with similar rates of other toxicities. The completion rate for planned treatment was also higher in the short hydration group.
population_specificity: Patients with lung or other cancers, Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2, receiving cisplatin chemotherapy at a dose of ≥60 mg/m².
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydration protocol included 1750-2250 ml with mannitol and magnesium supplementation).
study_duration: Single administration on Day 1 (3.75-4.75 hours for short hydration, 6.5-7.5 hours for conventional hydration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between magnesium levels and glycemic control in type 1 diabetes patients, as well as the potential benefits of magnesium supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium levels were lower in type 1 diabetes patients, particularly those with poor glycemic control, and that magnesium supplementation improved glycemic control and alleviated diabetes-induced complications in mouse models.
population_specificity: Type 1 diabetes patients and mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of magnesium and its transporter MAGT1 in human health and disease, particularly in immune responses and genetic disorders.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium and MAGT1 are crucial for T cell-mediated immune responses, with Mg2+ supplementation benefiting XMEN syndrome patients. However, the role of MAGT1 in intellectual disability was questioned.
population_specificity: Patients with XMEN syndrome and a family with atypical ATRX syndrome and skin abnormalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of magnesium supplementation on metabolic status and pregnancy outcomes in magnesium-deficient pregnant women with gestational diabetes (GDM).
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved metabolic markers (e.g., fasting glucose, insulin resistance) and pregnancy outcomes (e.g., reduced newborn hyperbilirubinemia and hospitalization rates) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Magnesium-deficient pregnant women with gestational diabetes (GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between hypomagnesaemia and outcomes like mortality, cardiovascular events, glucose metabolism, and graft dysfunction in kidney transplant recipients.
results_summary: Hypomagnesaemia in kidney transplant recipients is linked to aberrant glucose metabolism, higher diabetes incidence, and potential impacts on graft dysfunction, bone metabolism, and transplant immunology. Correcting magnesium deficiency may be challenging due to renal magnesium wasting.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant recipients, particularly in the early post-transplant period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of magnesium in metabolic pathways, its clinical significance in prediabetic and diabetic conditions, and the effects of magnesium supplementation on glycaemic control.
results_summary: The study found that reduced dietary magnesium intake is a risk factor for impaired glucose regulation and type 2 diabetes, and chronic magnesium supplementation may delay progression from impaired glucose regulation to diabetes. However, effects of supplementation on glycaemic control in type 2 diabetes were heterogeneous.
population_specificity: Prediabetic individuals (insulin resistance/impaired glucose tolerance) and type 2 diabetes patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of magnesium in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that magnesium inhibits vascular calcification through direct and indirect effects, and epidemiologic studies associate serum magnesium levels with cardiovascular outcomes in CKD patients, though intervention trials have been limited to surrogate parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a proprietary nutritional supplement containing magnesium, riboflavin, and Q10 as a prophylactic treatment for migraine.
results_summary: The supplement reduced migraine days per month (though not statistically significant compared to placebo), significantly reduced migraine pain intensity, and improved burden of disease and patient-reported efficacy compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with ≥3 migraine attacks per month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oral magnesium supplementation in reducing plasma glucose levels in adults with prediabetes and hypomagnesaemia.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced fasting and post-load glucose levels, HOMA-IR indices, and triglycerides, while increasing HDL cholesterol and serum magnesium levels. A higher percentage of participants in the magnesium group improved their glucose status compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30-65 years with hypomagnesaemia and newly diagnosed prediabetes.
effective_dosage: 30 mL of MgCl2 5% solution (equivalent to 382 mg of magnesium) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of oral magnesium supplementation on resistance exercise performance and vascular response after intense exercise, comparing acute (1-week) and chronic (4-week) loading strategies.
results_summary: Acute magnesium supplementation (1-week) improved bench press performance by 7.7% on day 1 and prevented performance decline on day 2, while chronic supplementation (4-week) led to a 32.1% decrease in performance on day 2. Both loading strategies reduced systolic blood pressure, but only acute loading reduced diastolic blood pressure and total peripheral resistance.
population_specificity: 13 participants in a randomized, double-blind, crossover, placebo-controlled study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the usefulness of existing research on magnesium supplementation during pregnancy for clinical advice.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that current research findings on magnesium supplementation during pregnancy are conflicting and may not provide clear, actionable guidance for practitioners.
population_specificity: Childbearing women and midwives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether magnesium-supplemented cardioplegia reduces cardiac injury after cardiac arrest surgery compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in most clinical outcomes between magnesium-supplemented and control groups, except for a marginal reduction in postoperative atrial fibrillation. The overall advantage of magnesium supplementation remained unconvincing.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cardiac arrest surgery (total of 1214 patients across 10 trials).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of nebulized magnesium sulfate as a bronchodilator in infants hospitalized with acute bronchiolitis, compared to nebulized epinephrine.
results_summary: Nebulized magnesium sulfate did not reduce hospital stay or improve oxygen use and vital signs compared to epinephrine, but it significantly improved the clinical respiratory distress score (RDAI).
population_specificity: 120 infants (mean age 5.1 months, 60% boys) with moderate to severe bronchiolitis.
study_duration: Duration of hospitalization (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of magnesium in migraine pathophysiology and assess the efficacy of oral magnesium supplementation for migraine prevention.
results_summary: The review identified limited evidence supporting oral magnesium supplementation for migraine prevention, suggesting dietary magnesium intake may be a preferable alternative. Only four intervention trials were found, indicating modest effects.
population_specificity: Migraine patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the physiological role of magnesium in human health and disease, focusing on its homeostasis and disturbances leading to hypomagnesemia.
results_summary: Magnesium plays a critical role in brain, heart, and skeletal muscle function, and supplementation has shown benefits in treating conditions like preeclampsia, migraine, depression, coronary artery disease, and asthma. The study also highlights genetic and drug-induced causes of hypomagnesemia.
population_specificity: General human health, with specific mentions of conditions like preeclampsia, migraine, depression, coronary artery disease, and asthma.
interactions: Mentioned interactions with diuretics, epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitors, calcineurin inhibitors, and proton pump inhibitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium infusion combined with varying hydration volumes could mitigate cisplatin-induced renal toxicity in lung cancer patients.
results_summary: High-volume hydration with magnesium infusion prevented significant changes in renal function markers, while low-volume hydration with magnesium showed a trend toward renal impairment. Magnesium infusion and high-volume hydration were independently associated with better renal outcomes.
population_specificity: 85 lung cancer patients receiving their first cycle of cisplatin-based chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome in adults using a dose-response meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found a significant inverse association between dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome risk, with a pooled relative risk of 0.88 per 150 mg/day increment in magnesium intake. The meta-regression showed a linear, inverse relationship, suggesting higher magnesium intake may reduce metabolic syndrome risk.
population_specificity: Adult population (cross-sectional and prospective cohort studies).
study_duration: Not specified (meta-analysis of studies from 1965 to 2014).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation improves metabolic control and insulin sensitivity in normomagnesemic type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation increased urinary magnesium excretion but did not significantly affect fasting glucose, HbA1c, insulin, HOMA-IR, or lipid profile. The study concluded that magnesium supplementation does not improve metabolic control or insulin sensitivity in this population.
population_specificity: Normomagnesemic subjects with type 2 diabetes (n=98, with 56 completing follow-up).
effective_dosage: 360 mg elemental magnesium (as magnesium lactate) daily.
study_duration: Three months per intervention phase, with a three-month washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of spironolactone on serum potassium and magnesium levels in CAPD patients with a history of hypokalemia.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of spironolactone on serum potassium, magnesium, or excretion rates in CAPD patients. One episode of hyperkalemia occurred during spironolactone treatment.
population_specificity: CAPD patients with a history of hypokalemia (20 completed the study, 10 anuric).
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention with a 2-week washout period.

study_goal: The study aimed to compare the benefits and harms of lipid-soluble formulations of amphotericin B with conventional amphotericin B in cancer patients with neutropenia, including the role of magnesium supplementation for nephrotoxicity prevention.
results_summary: The study found that lipid-based amphotericin B formulations reduced nephrotoxicity, but it was unclear if magnesium supplementation alone provided significant benefits under optimal administration conditions.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with neutropenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium citrate reduces the risk of placental dysfunction and indicated preterm delivery in high-risk pregnant women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be ongoing or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at higher risk for placental dysfunction, based on prior or current pregnancy clinical factors.
study_duration: From 12 1/7 to 20 6/7 weeks gestation until delivery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of magnesium supplements on hemodynamic and metabolic parameters in healthy men with a family history of metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in blood pressure, metabolic, inflammatory, or hemodynamic parameters after magnesium supplementation compared to placebo. Magnesium supplementation did not show beneficial effects on vascular function or glycolipid profile in the studied population.
population_specificity: Healthy normomagnesemic men aged 23-33 years with a family history of metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium supplementation reduces high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) levels in healthy individuals with prediabetes and hypomagnesemia.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly increased serum magnesium levels and decreased hsCRP levels compared to the placebo group, suggesting a beneficial effect on inflammation markers.
population_specificity: 62 men and non-pregnant women aged 18-65 with prediabetes and hypomagnesemia.
effective_dosage: 30 mL of MgCl2 5% solution once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral magnesium supplementation improves metabolic profile and blood pressure in metabolically obese, normal-weight (MONW) individuals with hypomagnesemia.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved systolic and diastolic blood pressure, HOMA-IR index, fasting glucose, and triglyceride levels compared to placebo. The intervention group showed clinically meaningful reductions in these metabolic markers.
population_specificity: Metabolically obese, normal-weight (MONW) individuals with hypomagnesemia.
effective_dosage: 30 mL of MgCl2 5% solution (equivalent to 382 mg magnesium) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize data on how Mg(2+), through TRPM6 and TRPM7 channel-kinases, impacts early embryonic development, particularly gastrulation and neural tube closure.
results_summary: The study found that Mg(2+) deficiency disrupts gastrulation and neural tube closure, and supplementation can prevent these defects. TRPM7 and TRPM6 channels play a critical role in Mg(2+) homeostasis during early development.
population_specificity: Rodents, frogs, and human studies (focus on embryonic development).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium preloading before cisplatin administration reduces cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity in thoracic malignancy patients.
results_summary: Magnesium preloading significantly reduced the incidence of Grade ≥2 serum creatinine elevation during both the first cycle (4.9% vs. 19.1%) and all cycles (14.2% vs. 39.7%) compared to non-magnesium preloading. Multivariate analysis confirmed magnesium preloading significantly reduced nephrotoxicity throughout the treatment period.
population_specificity: 496 thoracic malignancy patients treated with cisplatin (≥60 mg/m²)-containing regimens.
effective_dosage: 8 mEq magnesium preloading before cisplatin administration.
study_duration: Median of four cycles per group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of magnesium supplementation during pregnancy on maternal, neonatal/infant, and pediatric outcomes, including perinatal mortality, fetal growth restriction, and pre-eclampsia.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in perinatal mortality, small-for-gestational age, or pre-eclampsia between magnesium-supplemented and control groups. However, magnesium supplementation was associated with some secondary benefits, such as fewer babies with low Apgar scores and reduced maternal hospitalizations, though a possible increased risk of neonatal death was noted (likely due to confounding factors).
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds with low magnesium intakes.
effective_dosage: Varied by trial: magnesium oxide (1000 mg daily), magnesium citrate (340-365 mg daily), magnesium gluconate (2-4 g daily), magnesium aspartate (15 mmol or 365 mg daily), and magnesium stearate (128 mg elemental magnesium daily).
study_duration: Varied by trial, ranging from early pregnancy (≤4 months post-conception) until birth or hospitalization after 38 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of magnesium supplementation in the treatment of acquired Long QT syndrome (LQTS), particularly in high-risk ICU patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that magnesium supplementation, along with potassium, is part of the treatment strategy for acquired LQTS, alongside discontinuation of QT-prolonging drugs. Overdrive cardiac pacing is highlighted as highly effective, while antiarrhythmic drugs should be avoided.
population_specificity: ICU patients with risk factors for drug-induced LQTS, such as advanced age, structural heart disease, and impaired drug elimination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on circulating magnesium levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation significantly increased serum magnesium levels in both men and women with type 2 diabetes. In women, magnesium changes correlated positively with HDL-cholesterol and negatively with fasting glucose.
population_specificity: 126 adult Saudi patients (55 men, 71 women) with controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (mean age 53.6±10.7 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified for magnesium (vitamin D3 dosage: 2000 IU/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral magnesium supplementation in lowering blood pressure in hypertensive subjects on anti-hypertensive medication.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of seven studies showed a significant reduction in both systolic and diastolic blood pressure with magnesium supplementation, with large effect sizes. Other studies with less stringent criteria showed mixed results, suggesting variability in response.
population_specificity: Hypertensive subjects on anti-hypertensive medication for at least six months, with mean starting systolic blood pressure >155 mmHg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation improves physical performance in professional volleyball players, particularly in anaerobic metabolism and plyometric performance.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced lactate production and improved countermovement jump performance (by up to 3 cm) in the experimental group, though plasma magnesium levels decreased. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Twenty-five professional male volleyball players.
effective_dosage: 350 mg Mg per day for the experimental group, 500 mg maltodextrin per day for the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether concurrent magnesium administration with thiamine (Pabrinex) enhances the efficacy of thiamine treatment in chronic alcoholic patients, as measured by erythrocyte transketolase activity.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving magnesium sulphate with Pabrinex had a significantly greater increase in erythrocyte transketolase activity compared to those receiving Pabrinex alone, suggesting magnesium may be necessary for full thiamine efficacy.
population_specificity: Chronic alcoholic patients presenting acutely to the Accident and Emergency department.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intravenous Pabrinex supplemented with magnesium sulphate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of short hydration with magnesium sulfate in preventing renal dysfunction in lung cancer patients receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that adding magnesium sulfate to pre-hydration was effective, with 97.8% of patients completing chemotherapy without Grade 2 or higher renal dysfunction. Only one patient experienced a transient Grade 2 creatinine elevation, which improved promptly.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients (29 men, 15 women; median age 64) receiving cisplatin-based chemotherapy (≥75 mg/m²).
effective_dosage: 8 mEq of magnesium sulfate added to pre-hydration.
study_duration: Patients received three to four cycles of chemotherapy (median duration 4.0 hours per cycle).

study_goal: To determine if magnesium supplementation could prevent hypertension during the last part of pregnancy.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced diastolic blood pressure at week 37 and decreased the number of women with a ≥15 mmHg increase in diastolic blood pressure. An inverse relationship was found between urinary magnesium excretion and diastolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Pregnant primagravida women from a local antenatal care unit.
effective_dosage: 300 mg magnesium as citrate, oral supply.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation could improve body composition and muscle strength in middle-aged overweight women.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation (250 mg/day for 8 weeks) led to a significant increase in lean body mass and decrease in fat mass compared to baseline, but these changes were not significant compared to placebo. Handgrip strength and functional mobility improved in the magnesium group compared to baseline, but not significantly compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged overweight women (BMI 25–30 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of intravenous magnesium sulphate as a second-line treatment for severe asthma exacerbations in poorly responding patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous magnesium sulphate is a second-line treatment option for severe asthma exacerbations when first-line therapies (oxygen, bronchodilators, and glucocorticosteroids) fail to produce adequate responses. It is positioned above aminophylline in the treatment hierarchy.
population_specificity: Patients with severe asthma exacerbations requiring emergency treatment or hospitalization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of magnesium supplementation in preventing postoperative arrhythmias in pediatric patients undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation reduced the incidence of postoperative arrhythmias by 66% compared to placebo, with no heterogeneity between trials. The findings support magnesium's use as an alternative for preventing arrhythmias in this population, though higher-quality trials are needed for broader generalization.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the possible links between magnesium and depression in humans, including its role in prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Higher dietary magnesium intake was associated with lower depression symptoms, though reverse causality could not be excluded. Results on blood and cerebrospinal fluid magnesium levels were inconclusive, and while magnesium may be effective in treating depression, data are scarce and inconsistent.
population_specificity: Humans (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficiency of magnesium supplementation in reducing post-operative atrial fibrillation (AF) development following cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that magnesium supplementation is among the pharmacological agents associated with a reduction in post-operative AF frequency, though specific efficacy data are not detailed.
population_specificity: Cardiac surgery patients at risk of post-operative atrial fibrillation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sequential intravenous and oral magnesium supplementation could reduce pain intensity and improve lumbar spine mobility in patients with chronic low back pain with a neuropathic component.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplementation significantly reduced pain intensity and improved lumbar spine range of motion over a 6-month period compared to placebo. The magnesium group showed notable improvements in flexion, extension, and lateral flexion movements.
population_specificity: 80 patients with chronic low back pain (neuropathic component, Leeds Assessment of Neuropathic Signs and Symptoms score ≥ 12) receiving physical therapy.
effective_dosage: Intravenous magnesium infusion for 2 weeks followed by oral magnesium capsules for 4 weeks (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate magnesium flux and serum concentrations in ICU patients undergoing continuous venovenous haemodiafiltration (CVVHDF) with different anticoagulation methods.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium concentrations declined rapidly, particularly in patients receiving citrate anticoagulation, often falling below the reference range. Magnesium loss was greater with citrate, and subtherapeutic levels could occur before detection with once-daily sampling.
population_specificity: ICU patients receiving CVVHDF (22 circuits with citrate, 26 with heparin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium supplementation reduces inflammatory markers (hsCRP, TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-10) in prediabetic subjects with hypomagnesemia and inflammation.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly reduced hsCRP levels compared to placebo, but no significant changes were observed for TNF-alpha, IL-6, or IL-10. Intra-group analysis also showed no significant changes in hsCRP levels for the magnesium group.
population_specificity: Prediabetic men and non-pregnant women with hypomagnesemia and inflammation (n=26).
effective_dosage: 382 mg magnesium daily (as 30 ml of MgCl₂ 5% solution).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effect of oral magnesium supplementation on respiratory muscle strength and clinical outcomes in children and adolescents with cystic fibrosis.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly improved urinary magnesium levels, respiratory muscle strength (MIP and MEP), and clinical outcomes (SK score) compared to placebo. The improvements were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with cystic fibrosis (aged 7-19 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of oral magnesium in reducing the frequency and intensity of pregnancy-induced leg cramps.
results_summary: The study found that oral magnesium significantly reduced both the frequency (86.0% vs. 60.5%) and intensity (69.8% vs. 48.8%) of leg cramps compared to placebo, with no significant differences in side effects between groups.
population_specificity: 86 healthy pregnant women, 14-34 weeks of gestation, experiencing leg cramps at least twice per week.
effective_dosage: 300 mg magnesium bisglycinate chelate per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of magnesium supplementation compared to no treatment, placebo, or other therapies for preventing skeletal muscle cramps in various patient groups.
results_summary: Magnesium showed no statistically significant benefit for idiopathic cramps in older adults, with small, non-significant effects on cramp frequency, intensity, and duration. For pregnancy-associated cramps, results were conflicting, with one study showing no benefit and another showing some improvement.
population_specificity: Older adults with idiopathic cramps and pregnant women with leg cramps.
study_duration: Four weeks for primary outcomes in idiopathic cramp trials.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of silymarin, not Magnesium, in maintaining remission in ulcerative colitis patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not report any findings specific to Magnesium's effects, as it was only mentioned as a component of the placebo tablet (magnesium stearate).
population_specificity: 80 ulcerative colitis patients in remission.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Magnesium (only mentioned as part of placebo composition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether magnesium supplementation could reduce seizures in people with epilepsy.
results_summary: Some studies suggest lower magnesium levels in people with epilepsy, and case reports indicate seizure control with magnesium supplementation. A trial showed better response to ACTH plus magnesium than ACTH alone in children with infantile spasms.
population_specificity: People with epilepsy, including children with infantile spasms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral magnesium pidolate (MgP) is superior to placebo in reducing premature ventricular and supraventricular complexes (PVC and PsVC) and improving symptoms in symptomatic patients.
results_summary: The study found that 76.6% of patients in the MgP group had a >70% reduction in premature complex density, compared to only 40% in the placebo group showing slight improvement. Symptom improvement was achieved in 93.3% of MgP-treated patients versus 16.7% in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 60 symptomatic patients (55% female, aged 16-70) with >240 PVC or PsVC on 24-hour Holter monitoring, without structural heart disease or renal failure.
effective_dosage: 3.0 g/day of MgP (equivalent to 260 mg elemental magnesium).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of magnesium levels in drinking water with blood pressure and metabolic syndrome components in a healthy population.
results_summary: Higher magnesium levels in drinking water were associated with lower diastolic blood pressure, higher serum magnesium, and lower serum Ca/Mg ratio, suggesting potential benefits for hypertension and metabolic syndrome prevention.
population_specificity: 90 healthy blood donors aged 20-50 years from three municipalities in Serbia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (natural magnesium levels in drinking water: 11 mg/L vs. 42 mg/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between magnesium intake and the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, based on evidence from epidemiological studies and clinical trials.
results_summary: Epidemiological studies consistently show an inverse relationship between dietary magnesium intake and type 2 diabetes risk, but clinical trial results on magnesium supplementation's effects on glucose metabolism and insulin sensitivity are scarce and controversial.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on type 2 diabetes risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of magnesium deficiency in thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) and the effects of magnesium supplementation on mitigating TMA development, severity, and recurrence.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that magnesium supplementation could improve endothelial function, reduce platelet aggregability, and decrease inflammation in TMA, based on in vitro and in vivo evidence, but no direct human trial results are reported.
population_specificity: Theoretical focus on individuals with thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA), including conditions like haemolytic uraemic syndrome and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of magnesium supplementation on blood pressure and identify trial characteristics associated with the largest effect size.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation resulted in a small but clinically significant reduction in blood pressure (SBP: 3-4 mm Hg, DBP: 2-3 mm Hg), with greater effects seen in crossover trials and higher dosages (>370 mg/day). The effect size increased with dosage, though not all individual trials showed significant reductions.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population, n=1173 across 22 trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between proton pump inhibitor (PPI) use and hypomagnesaemia/hypokalemia, focusing on magnesium homeostasis and transport mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that esomeprazole (a PPI) was associated with hypomagnesaemia and hypokalemia, which partially resolved with oral magnesium supplementation and fully corrected after PPI discontinuation. Rechallenge with esomeprazole led to recurrence, supporting a causal relationship.
population_specificity: A 59-year-old man with irritability and hypomagnesaemia/hypokalemia while using esomeprazole.
interactions: Proton pump inhibitors (esomeprazole) were noted to interact with magnesium homeostasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of magnesium supplementation in preventing refeeding syndrome in severely malnourished children.
results_summary: The study found that magnesium supplements, along with phosphate and potassium, are recommended to avoid refeeding syndrome in severely malnourished children, suggesting their efficacy in this context.
population_specificity: Severely malnourished children with poor oral intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sensitive and population-specific biomarkers of magnesium status to understand human magnesium requirements and its health effects.
results_summary: The study found that serum/plasma magnesium concentration, red blood cell magnesium concentration, and urinary magnesium excretion responded to dietary manipulation, suggesting their usefulness as biomarkers. Data for other biomarkers were insufficient to draw conclusions.
population_specificity: Healthy humans (general population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative magnesium sulphate (MgSO₄) supplementation affects the minimal alveolar concentration (MAC) of desflurane and hemodynamic responses during intubation.
results_summary: The study found that MgSO₄ reduced the MAC of desflurane and suppressed hemodynamic responses (tachycardia and hypertension) during intubation, but prolonged recovery times (extubation, verbal cooperation, and eye opening).
population_specificity: Sixty patients undergoing abdominal surgery under general anesthesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of adding 100 mg magnesium sulfate to intrathecal bupivacaine on spinal anesthesia outcomes in lower extremity orthopedic surgery.
results_summary: The addition of magnesium sulfate prolonged sensory block duration (106.5 vs. 85.5 min) and reduced postoperative analgesic needs (96.8 vs. 138.5 mg), but delayed sensory block onset (13.3 vs. 11.6 min). Spinal anesthesia duration did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: ASA I or II adult patients undergoing lower extremity orthopedic surgery.
effective_dosage: 100 mg MgSO₄ (5%, 0.2 ml) intrathecally, single dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with magnesium, vitamin B2, and vitamin B6 reduces urinary dicarboxylic acid levels in autistic children.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation significantly reduced urinary levels of succinic, adipic, and suberic acids in autistic children after 3 months of treatment.
population_specificity: Autistic children (n=30)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if micronutrient supplementation, including magnesium, could improve neuropathy indices in type 2 diabetes patients.
